instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.D7010: What is D7010? Diode between ground and gate of Q7010 on 2013-2015 year retina model macbook pros, necessary for Q7010 to allow PPDCIN_G3H to flow through to PP3V42_G3H power supply input. When this diode dies or corrodes, PP3V42_G3H input will not have any voltage, and chargers will not turn on. This can often be the problem if a system only works with a knockoff charger/bench power supply. .
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .
definitions.A1425: What is A1425? A1425 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Early 2013, Late 2012 with EMC 2672, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3190, 820-3462..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A completely dead no green light <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message: Hi, have this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Board which is completely dead no green light. <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0V. My DC IN Board and genuine MagSafe Charger are known good. Aynone got a idea? I habe no idea on the history, just that it had a prior repair

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A completely dead no green light <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
We always expect to get some voltages and signals in the first post; this helps a lot.
Check 3V42/<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

Be aware of FDMF6808 nightmare on these boards...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A completely dead no green light <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 0V
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A completely dead no green light <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
You have some time on the forum.
So we expect to post more usefull information; is your interest to gain time...

Didn't check if any short?
Some basic voltages for <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A completely dead no green light <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message: Sorry for the lack of information, Iâ€™ve just never had this exact issue and was quite frankly a bit confused about everything being 0V.... Measured all pins on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and all are 0v...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A completely dead no green light <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
Looks like input leakage.
We still need more tests and measurments...

Did you try fake charger, or lab power supply?
Post exact <RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> value; ohm scale, onboard.
Same for <RESISTOR>R7180</RESISTOR>/81 and <RESISTOR>R7185</RESISTOR>/86.
Check if <DIODE>D7010</DIODE> is not open, or shorted.
Post <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> voltages too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A completely dead no green light <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message: Have no fake chargers around here. In order to power with a DC Power Supply do I have to chop up a irking MagSafe 2 Charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A completely dead no green light <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
You will need Magsafe 2 85W cable, which can power any board.

What about the other indiciouses I gave you???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A completely dead no green light <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message: Oh sorry I thought I posted those too guess I accidentally deleted the post instead of posting it or something like that...  But tbh I don't think the other Voltages will be required. Upon plugging in the Charger with the DC Supply it went green and then orange before literally burning a hole in the board... The connector was already removed by another shop before...Have a look at this mess.... Is there a chance of salvaging it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A completely dead no green light <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message: Yup it sure is. There must be some massive short here because the power supply output is dragged down to about 5v with a current draw of the maximum 5A.... Cleaning it did nothing it still smokes like crazy whenever I apply power. Also no more green light...
